text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- President Franjo Tudjman visited Beli Manastir on Monday, the second-biggest town in Serb-held Eastern Slavonia, and said his visit was proof that Croatia's leaders were serious about completing the peaceful reintegration of the region with the rest of the country.
- Croatia kick-started its mass voucher privatisation scheme on Monday, expected to include more than 400,000 people.

- The new Croatian special envoy for co-operation with the Moslem-Croat Bosnian Federation, Franjo Greguric, says economic co-operation between Croatia and the Federation will speed the implementation of the Dayton peace agreement.

- "Are Croatian team sports -- soccer, basketball, handball and waterpolo -- on the decline?," asks one commentator, following a recent streak of bad results at international level from national teams.
- Presidential candidate Vlado Gotovac of Social Liberals threatened to withdraw from the race if the state-controlled media continue to "turn the election campaign into a farce".
- The other opposition candidate, Social Democrat Zdravko Tomac, said "my chances of winning are growing".
- Ministry of employment and social care and public service unions start new round of wage talks
- A leased A-320, the first Airbus-type airplane in the Croatian Airlines fleet, started flying on its route between Zagreb and London.

- The head of the Croatian Peasant Party, the third strongest opposition party, comes under strong pressure from his party to resign after bad results in April's local election. -- Zagreb Newsroom 385-1-4557075
